Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc. continually reviews implemented operating procedures for potential safety improvements for all of its operations.  Currently, Beaver Street management team and Process Safety Team are reviewing potential improvements to the existing design of the ammonia operations to make the system even safer to prevent a release and minimize consequences in the event of a release of ammonia.

1.	Executive Summary 68.155
Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc. is located at 1741 West Beaver Street, Duval County, Jacksonville, FL  32209.  The Beaver Street facility has over a threshold quantity of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated highly hazardous chemical per EPA's 40 CFR-68.  Beaver Street has a unified Risk Management Program as well as OSHA Process Safety Management program that are presented in this summary.

1.1.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES (a)
Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc. accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures and management practices.  The plant prevention program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) 40 CFR-68, Prevention Program.  It also complies with the like requirements of 29-CFR 1910.119 OSHA PSM program.

1.1.1.	MANAGEMENT SYSTEM(a) (1)
	Beaver Street has a management system in place which is lead by the Fisheries' Vice President, who oversees the implementation and on-going use of the RMP elements.  This program, along with other facility-specific policies, eliminates and/or reduces the likelihood of an ammonia release at the facility.  An organization chart defines the lines of authority and list responsible staff.  It is included in the plant's Process Safety Information.

1.1.2.	PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 3 (a) (2)
Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc. maintains policies, procedures and systems as part of their prevention program.  The program addresses each of the EPA Program Level 3-listed 12 elements, plus OSHA elements needed to implement the program.  These are maintained in the Beaver Street plant Document Management System (DMS).  The unified PSM/RMP program was implemented in 2004 prior to increasing the maximum inventory above the 10,000 pound threshold.  Beaver Street employs 225 fulltime and 132 staffing service employees engaged in facility and field operations

.  

1.1.3.	SITE DESCRIPTION (b) (1)
	The site is owned and operated by Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc.  The site is located at 1741 West Beaver Street, City of Jacksonville, in Duval County, Florida.  The site is bordered by Robinson Avenue on the west, railroad tracks on the east, McQuade Street on the north and West Beaver Street on the south.
	The Plant includes an ammonia storage compressor and transfer system in its Engine Room.  There is an adjacent Control Room system.  The boundaries of the ammonia system subject to the RMP regulation include the Bulk Ammonia Storage and Feed Control rooms and the associated vent makeup and exhaust systems.  Ammonia liquid is delivered to numerous evaporators (refrigerator units located throughout the plant) and returns to the Engine Room and it is liquefied in the rooftop condensers for further use.  These are detailed in the Process and Instrument Drawings (P&ID) which are part of the plant Process Safety Information (PSI).  

1.1.4.	REGULATED SUBSTANCE (b) (2)
	Anhydrous Ammonia is the only regulated substance on site which exceeds the EPA 40 CFR-68 rule 10,000 pound, as well as the OSHA PSM threshold quantity.  Beaver Street's ammonia process was installed as part of the process of supplying plant refrigeration.  It operates under permit from the State of Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FL DEP).  The ammonia is stored in a receiver and distributed to the refrigerator process control systems. 
	Anhydrous ammonia is a toxic chemical; it is an irritant and is corrosive.  Ammonia's formula is NH3.  The OSHA PEL is 50 ppm.  It is flammable and is a gas at standard conditions.  Ammonia is liquefied by compression.
1.2.	WORST AND ALTERNATIVE CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS (c)
Two offsite consequence analyses were conducted which include two ammonia release scenarios.  The first is a Worst Case Release Scenario.  The second is more probable Alternative Release Scenario.  Results are depicted on an aerial map in

aporators flows back into the high temp tank.  The plant and support equipment of the ammonia compressor room and control room meet and exceed design codes standards and good engineering practices.  

1.3.2.3.	Equipment Design
The process is built to good engineering requirements for an ammonia refrigeration system. These materials of construction are steel or ammonia compatible metallic and non-metallic compounds (not corroded by ammonia).  The ammonia pipe system is designed using schedule 80 seamless pipe designed to 2,500 psig.  The typical high pressure of the ammonia system is 145 psig giving a large safety factor.
The Engine Room has a ventilation system, as well as an eye wash safety shower.  Relief valves are installed on the tanks and compressors. The relief valves all vent to a single stack outside and high above the Engine Room as ammonia is buoyant.  There are ammonia monitors in the Engine Room which detect the presence of ammonia.  The monitor system sounds an alarm and turns on a warning light in the Engine Room and adjacent control room/office.  

1.4.	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (e)
There have been zero EPA recorded accidents in the past five years.  

1.5.	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM (f)
Emergency response procedures are contained in the Plant Emergency Response Policy and coordinated with the City of Jacksonville (Emergency Response Plan) and the LEPC.  The plan includes an emergency response decision tree and a notification plan.  The Plant also has site specific emergency actions defined in the plants operating procedures.  Emergency response drills and drill evacuations are conducted.  Emergency operation and response procedures are also reviewed annually.
The emergency response program (contingency plan) is coordinated (reviewed by) with the Plant Wide Safety Committee, the Jacksonville Fire Department who staffs the nearby City Fire/Rescue Station.  The plant coordinates with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the C

emands training of contractors to our standards. 

1.3.2.	AMMONIA-SPECIFIC RESPONSE PROGRAM (d) (2)

1.3.2.1.	Ammonia-Specific Policies-Procedures
Chemical-specific prevention features of the plant include: the policies and procedures listed above and those of the ammonia specific program.  These include:
¿	Specific procedures for the operation of the ammonia process are outlined below. 
¿	Completion of a Pre-startup Safety Review prior to startup of the ammonia system.  The latest one was conducted in December, 2003 for the added equipment as part of the project expansion.
¿	Specific emergency response procedures for ammonia releases as outlined below under both operating procedures and in the emergency response procedures.  
¿	Specific training in the properties, hazards, handling requirements, and operations level leak repair for ammonia.  
¿	Finally, the details of the facility and equipment design are key to the safe operations of the ammonia system.  
1.3.2.2.	Ammonia Feed System Design
The ammonia storage and process area is in the Engine Room and Control Room office.  The Engine Room houses a two stage refrigeration system which feeds both freezers and coolers, the cool doc and production areas.  The low temperature system pumps liquid ammonia from the low temp tank to the evaporators (freezers).  Ammonia vaporizes and then flows back to the low temp tank.  Vapor from the tank feeds vapor to the low side compressors.  The output of those compressors supplies the high temp tank.  Ammonia vapors from the high temp tank feed the high side compressors.  The compressor discharge at 145 psig vapor flows to the condensers located on the roof.  They cool and condense the high temperature vapors back to a liquid.  The liquid then flows into the high pressure liquid receiver.  Liquid ammonia under a pressure of 145 psig flows into the high temp evaporators (refrigeration systems for the Coolers, the Cool Doc and Cool Work Areas).  Ammonia gas from these ev

ity of Jacksonville Fire Department HazMat team.  All are located in Duval County, Florida.  Copies of the program are given to key local agencies including: fire, medical, rescue, management, and police departments in the City of Jacksonville and Duval County.  Besides the specific emergency response program, key elements of the prevention programs are incorporated in the operating culture of the Beaver Street plant.
The Contingency Plan procedures detail the actions and responses to an ammonia spill (release).  The plan includes training of all ammonia-area operator and maintenance staff to the HazMat Operations Level.  The primary response team includes the Jacksonville Fire and Rescue, plus the Haz Mat Team.  All of these respond to severe ammonia leak situations.  Actions include catastrophic, severe, and moderate leaks.  Public notification is facilitated through the City of Jacksonville Fire Rescue, Police and Duval County Emergency Management Office, which has an automated emergency dialing message system for public notification.
1.5.1.	PERSONNEL (f) (1)
	Personnel are the key resource of the Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc. prevention program. Plant employees make up the operators and emergency response teams.  Beaver Street fosters a high level of involvement in every aspect of the ammonia system operation.
¿	RMP safety teams. 
¿	Development of the operation procedures. 
¿	Hazard evaluations and Process Hazards Analysis. 
¿	On-going training of the operators and other ammonia involved staff.

1.6.	CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY (g)
Changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified in the recent internal safety tour and audit of the RMP program to meet requirements of the Risk Management Prevention Program.  These recommended actions have now been evaluated and implemented as required.  A Process Hazard Analysis was conducted in September 2014 to review the RMP program.  The key safety action items included resubmission of the RMP*eSubmit to

the plant's Process Safety Information. The first scenario is defined by EPA, which states that the operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released as a gas over 10 minutes due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative scenario is defined as more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario.
Atmospheric dispersion modeling was performed using RMP Comp to determine the distance traveled by the ammonia released before its concentration decreases to the toxic endpoint.  The EPA specified endpoint for ammonia is 0.14 mg/l. This endpoint is the Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2).  This is defined by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) as the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual's ability to take protective action.  The residential population within a circle with a radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance was defined based on the 2010 census.  The potential affected population and environmental receptors are identified.

1.2.1.	WORST CASE (c) (1)
	The results of the Worst Case Release Scenario are discussed in detail in the plant RMP program Process Safety Information.  The methodology to determine the distance to the worst case end point and impacts for this release follows EPA guidelines for a worst case release.  Modeling used was EPA's RMP Comp.

1.2.2.	ALTERNATIVE CASE (c) (2)
	The results of an Alternate Case Release Scenario are discussed in detail in the plant RMP program Process Safety Information.  The methodology to determine the distance to the alternate case end point and impacts for this release follows EPA guidelines for an alternate case release.

1.3.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM(d)
Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc.'s accidental release preventio

n program is based on EPA's RMP Level 3 prevention program and similar OSHA PSM program.  The program has been in place and effectively used for over sixteen years.  It is part of the facility's operating culture.  There are two parts to the program.  The first is the general overall plant wide program.  The second is the ammonia-specific actions within the site program.  This is coordinated with the City of Jacksonville Fire/Rescue, and Haz Mat Team as well as the Jacksonville Sheriff's Department. .

1.3.1.	GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (d) (1)
	Plant-wide, many elements of the prevention program are used for all operations.  An overview of the general programs is listed below:
¿	Beaver Street Fisheries, Inc. has detailed process safety information on each of its operations.  
¿	The plant document maintenance system is integral to the management of change for all operations on site control.  
¿	Training and on the job experience is the backbone of employee knowledge, job operations and is ongoing in each area.  Employee training in operations and maintenance emphas awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of all chemicals used. 
¿	Maintenance and preventive maintenance are used for all operations making mechanical integrity a part of each piece of equipment. 
¿	Incident investigations of accidents and near-miss incidents ensure we learn from each event as well as correct the causes of the incident.  We have had zero RMP reportable accidents.
¿	Employees participate in all aspects of the plant operations including the Process Hazards Analysis, Audits and review of procedures.  
¿	Safe work practices are used throughout the facility including:  1) Hot Work Permits, 2) Lockout/Tagout, 3) Confined Space/Vessel Entry Permits, 4) Site Security, 5) Breaking Into Chemical Lines Permit Procedure. 
¿	Contractors must meet Beaver Street's high safety and technical standards as part of selection and ongoing evaluations.  Plus, Beaver Street d
